0.body: This book is for people who are writing APIs in Rust. In particular, APIs that involve complex abstractions: variadics, state machines, extensible architectures, and so on. The central theme is how to enforce API invariants by replacing dynamically-typed abstractions with statically-typed ones.
0.title: Rust API Type Patterns

1.breadcrumbs: A prototypical example: enums over strings
1.title: A prototypical example: enums over strings

2.body: The remainder of the book is structured much like the example above. Each chapter follows the pattern: Describe the concepts and constraints of a system in a particular application domain. Show the dynamically-typed and statically-typed implementations of an API for the system. Analyze what errors can happen in each flavor of API. You can consume this book Ã  la carte, reading individual chapters as they're useful to you. But I have done my best to build a narrative thread between chapters. The content is ordered roughly from least to most complex. TODO: explain the thread.
2.title: Book structure

3.body: An API is a computational representation of real-world concepts, and a good API has a small distance between the representation and the concept . This begs the question: what defines such a distance?
3.title: The Main Idea

4.title: Principles of representation
